Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of 3D Simulation for Preoperative Understanding of Aesthetic Outcome in Breast-Conserving Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised into three groups

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised into three groups: standard care (verbal description alone), viewing two-dimensional (2D) photographs, or viewing a 3D simulation.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate whether a three-dimensional (3D) simulation enhances patients' confidence in understanding their likely aesthetic outcome after surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the median score on a visual analogue scale (VAS) assessing confidence in knowing the likely aesthetic outcome, measured before surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was stratified by BMI, axillary lymph node dissection intention, and operation type, with allocation concealment ensured by a central computer program.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between May 2017 and October 2019, 41 participants were randomised to the control group, 39 to the 2D-photograph group, and 37 to the 3D simulation group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 41 participants were randomised to the control group, 39 to the 2D-photograph group, and 37 to the 3D simulation group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The median VAS scores were 5.2 (i.q.r. 2.6–7.8) for the control, 8.0 (i.q.r. 5.7–8.7) for 2D photography, and 8.9 (i.q.r. 8.2–9.5) for 3D simulation, with significant differences between groups (P < 0.010).
